column1: Fargo is a city in and the county seat of Cass County
column3: United States. Being the most populous city in the state
column4: it accounts for nearly 17% of the state population. According to the 2019 United States Census estimates
column5: its population was 124
column7: making it the 223rd-most populous city in the United States. Fargo
column8: along with its twin city of Moorhead
column10: as well as the adjacent cities of West Fargo
column13: form the core of the Fargo-Moorhead
column15: which in 2019 contained a population of 246
column16: 145.Founded in 1871 on the Red River of the North floodplain
column21: and industrial center for eastern North Dakota and northwestern Minnesota. The city is also home to North Dakota State University.

column1: == History ==
=== Early history ===
Historically part of Sioux (Dakota) territory
column2: the area that is present-day Fargo was an early stopping point for steamboats traversing the Red River during the 1870s and 1880s. The city was originally named "Centralia
column3: but was later renamed Fargo" after Northern Pacific Railway director and Wells Fargo Express Company founder William Fargo (1818–1881). The area started to flourish after the arrival of the Northern Pacific Railroad and the city became known as the "Gateway to the West."

column1: During the 1880s
column2: Fargo became the "divorce capital" of the Midwest because of lenient divorce laws.A major fire struck the city on June 7
column4: destroying 31 blocks of downtown Fargo
column5: but the city was immediately rebuilt with new buildings made of brick
column7: and a water system. More than 246 new buildings were built within one year. There were several rumors concerning the cause of the fire.The North Dakota Agricultural College was founded in 1890 as North Dakota's land-grant university
column8: becoming first accredited by the North Central Association in 1915. In 1960
column9: NDAC became known as North Dakota State University.

column1: === 20th century ===
Early in the century
column3: and in 1905
column4: Fargo became home to the Pence Automobile Company.On Labor Day in 1910
column5: Theodore Roosevelt visited Fargo to lay the cornerstone of the college's new library.  To a crowd of 30
column7: Roosevelt spoke about his first visit to Fargo 27 years earlier
column8: and credited his experience homesteading in North Dakota for his eventual rise to the presidency.Fargo-Moorhead boomed after World War II
column9: and the city grew rapidly despite a violent F5 tornado in 1957 that destroyed a large part of the north end of the city. Ted Fujita
column10: famous for his Fujita tornado scale
column11: analyzed pictures of the Fargo tornado
column12: which helped him develop his ideas for "wall cloud" and "tail cloud." These were the first major scientific descriptive terms associated with tornadoes. The construction of two interstates (I-29 and I-94) revolutionized travel in the region and pushed growth of Fargo to the south and west of the city limits. In 1972
column14: the largest shopping mall in North Dakota
column15: was constructed near the intersection of the two Interstates. This mall became a catalyst for retail growth in the area.

column1: === Recent history ===
Fargo has continued to expand rapidly but steadily. Since the mid-1980s
column2: the bulk of new residential growth has occurred in the south and southwest areas of the city due to geographic constraints on the north side. The city's major retail districts on the southwest side have likewise seen rapid development.

column1: Downtown Fargo has been gentrified due in part to investments by the city and private developers in the Renaissance Zone. Most older neighborhoods
column3: have either avoided decline or been revitalized through housing rehabilitation promoted by planning agencies to strengthen the city's core.

column1: NDSU has grown rapidly into a major research university
column2: and forms a major component of the city's identity and economy. Most students live off-campus in the surrounding Roosevelt neighborhood. The university has established a presence downtown through both academic buildings and apartment housing. In addition
column3: NDSU Bison Football has become a major sport following among many area residents.

column1: Since the late 1990s
column2: the Fargo-Moorhead Metropolitan Statistical Area has consistently had one of the lowest unemployment rates among MSAs in the United States. Coupled with Fargo's low crime rate and the decent supply of affordable housing in the community
column3: this has prompted Money magazine to rank the city near the top of its annual list of America's most livable cities throughout the late 1990s and early 2000s.

column1: Recently Fargo has been ranked by ZipRecruiter as the "#1 Hottest Job Market". Zippia ranked Fargo as the "#1 city to start a career." Today ranked Fargo as the "#3 best place to raise kids."
== Geography ==
Fargo is a core city of the Fargo-Moorhead metropolitan area
column3: West Fargo
column4: and Dilworth as well as outlying communities.

column1: Fargo sits on the western bank of the Red River of the North in a flat geographic region known as the Red River Valley. The Red River Valley resulted from the withdrawal of glacial Lake Agassiz
column3: 300 years ago. The lake sediments deposited from Lake Agassiz made the land around Fargo some of the richest in the world for agricultural uses.

column1: Fargo's largest challenge is the seasonal floods due to the rising water of the Red River
column2: which flows from the United States into Lake Winnipeg in Manitoba
column3: Canada. The Red flows northward
column4: which means melting snow and river ice
column5: as well as runoff from its tributaries
column6: often create ice dams causing the river to overflow. Fargo's surrounding Red River Valley terrain is essentially flat
column7: leading to overland flooding. Since the potentially devastating 2009 Red River flood
column8: both Fargo and Moorhead have taken great strides in flood protection
column9: only a near record flood would cause concern today.

column1: Its location makes the city vulnerable to flooding during seasons with above average precipitation. The Red River's minor flood stage in Fargo begins at a level of 18 feet
column2: with major flooding categorized at 30 feet and above. Many major downtown roadways and access to Moorhead are closed off at this level. Record snowfalls late in 1996 led to flooding in 1997
column3: causing the Red to rise to a record crest of 39.5 feet
column4: nearly overtaking city defenses. In 2008–2009
column5: significant fall precipitation coupled with a rapid snowmelt in March 2009 caused the Red to rise to a new record level of 40.84 feet
column7: in large part due to flood mitigation efforts instituted after the 1997 event and sandbagging efforts by the city residents. Further upgrades were made to city infrastructure and additional resources brought to bear following the 2009 flood
column8: which caused no issues for the city in 2010 despite another rapid melt that caused the Red to rise to 37 feet (which ranks among the top ten highest levels ever recorded). Recent discussions have focused on a $1.5 billion diversion project to channel the Red's water away from the city
column9: but such a project is in the planning stages and being evaluated by various government agencies. As of 2012
column10: Fargo has bought 700 houses in flood-prone areas.According to the United States Census Bureau
column11: the city has an area of 48.82 square miles (126.44 km2)

column1: === Climate ===
Because of its location in the Great Plains and its distance from both mountains and oceans
column2: Fargo has a humid continental climate (Köppen Dfa/Dfb)
column3: featuring cold winters and warm to hot
column4: humid summers. It lies in USDA Plant hardiness zone 4a. The city features winters among the coldest in the contiguous United States; the coldest month of January has a normal mean temperature of 9.3 °F (−12.6 °C). There is an annual average of 43 days with a minimum of 0 °F (−18 °C) or lower. Snowfall averages 50.1 inches (127 cm) per season. Spring and autumn are short and highly variable seasons. Summers have frequent thunderstorms
column5: and the warmest month
column7: has a normal mean temperature of 71.0 °F (21.7 °C); highs reach 90 °F (32 °C) on an average of 12.7 days each year. Annual precipitation of 22.6 inches (574 mm) is concentrated in the warmer months. Record temperatures have ranged from −48 °F (−44 °C) on January 8
column9: 1936; the record coldest daily maximum is −29 °F (−34 °C) on January 22
column13: the record warmest daily minimum was 82 °F (28 °C)
column14: set four days after the all-time record high. On average
column15: the first and last dates to see a minimum at or below the freezing mark are September 30 and May 8
column17: allowing a growing season of 144 days.In 2011
column18: Fargo won The Weather Channel's "America's Toughest Weather City" poll. Almost 850
column22: and floods secured the title for the city.

column1: == Law and government ==

Fargo uses the city commission style of local government. Four commissioners and a mayor are elected at large for four year terms. Dr. Tim Mahoney is Fargo's current mayor.  The Fargo City Commission meets every two weeks in its chambers above the Fargo Civic Center. The meetings are broadcast on a Government-access television (GATV) cable channel. In 2017
column2: there was an attempt to recall City Commissioner Dave Piepkorn by a group who argued his constant expressing of concern over refugee resettlement in the city was a xenophobic dog-whistle meant to rile up anti-refugee sentiment in the community. While the group says it did reach the required number of signatures
column3: it ultimately chose not to submit them because they did not know how many signatures would be eliminated in the review process
column4: and Commissioner Piepkorn threatened to obtain the list of signers via FOIA request
column5: which was interpreted as a political threat by the group.In 2018
column6: Fargo became the first city in the U.S. to use approval voting for elections.Fargo was historically a Republican-leaning area. As recently as the 2004 presidential election
column7: George W. Bush carried Fargo as well as the rest of Cass County with nearly 60 percent of the vote in both areas. Fargo has become more politically diverse and competitive. Since 2008
column8: no Republican presidential candidate has received over 50% of the vote in Cass County. In 2008
column9: Democratic candidate Barack Obama won the majority of votes in Cass County
column10: with a voting percentage very close to the percentage Obama received in the entire nation
column11: while John McCain won the majority of votes in North Dakota. Mitt Romney's winning margin in 2012 over Barack Obama in Cass County was 49.9% to 47% while Donald Trump received 49.3% of votes in 2016 compared to 38.8% against Hillary Clinton and 11.9% for third party candidates. In 2018
column12: Democratic Senator Heidi Heitkamp achieved a 14-point lead in Eastern North Dakota even though the state as a whole soundly elected Republican Kevin Cramer.

column1: == Economy ==

The economy of the Fargo area has historically been dependent on agriculture. That dominance has decreased substantially in recent decades. Today the city of Fargo has a growing economy based on food processing
column3: technology
column4: retail trade
column5: higher education
column6: and healthcare. In a study published by Forbes
column7: Fargo was ranked the best small city in the nation to start a business or a career.

column1: == Education ==
The Fargo Public Schools system serves most of the city
column3: three middle schools
column4: and four high schools: Fargo North High School
column5: Fargo South High School
column6: Judge Ronald N. Davies High School
column7: and an alternative high school (Woodrow Wilson). The original high school in the city was Central High School.

column1: The West Fargo Public Schools system serves the southwestern part of the city
column2: in addition to West Fargo itself and the surrounding communities of Horace and Harwood.

column1: In addition to public schools
column2: a number of private schools also operate in the city. The John Paul II Catholic Schools Network operates Holy Spirit Elementary
column3: Nativity Elementary
column4: Sullivan Middle School
column5: and Shanley High School. Additionally
column6: the Oak Grove Lutheran School and Park Christian School (which is in Moorhead
column7: Minnesota) serve grades pre-K through 12
column8: while Grace Lutheran School serves grades pre-K through 8.

column1: === Higher education ===
Fargo is home to North Dakota State University (NDSU)
column3: 500 students. NDSU was founded in 1890 as the state land grant university focusing on agriculture
column4: engineering and science
column5: but has since branched out to cover many other fields of study. NDSU
column6: along with Minnesota State University Moorhead and Concordia College in Moorhead
column7: form the Tri-College University system of Fargo-Moorhead. Students can take classes at any of the three institutions. These three colleges also form a vibrant student-youth community of over 25

column1: NDSCS-Fargo is a campus of North Dakota State College of Science. Located in the Skills and Technology Training Center on 19th Avenue North in Fargo
column2: NDSCS-Fargo serves as the home to academic programming and non-credit training.

column1: Fargo is also home to several private collegiate institutions
column3: a branch location of the University of Mary
column4: and Masters Baptist College operated by Fargo Baptist Church.  The University of Jamestown's Doctor of Physical Therapy program is based in Fargo.

column1: === Libraries ===
The Fargo Public Library was established in 1900 and for many years was housed in a Carnegie-funded building. In 1968
column2: the library moved into a new facility as part of urban renewal efforts in the downtown area.  The original 1968 building was demolished and replaced with a new library which opened in 2009. In addition
column3: Fargo Public Library operates the Dr. James Carlson Library in south Fargo
column4: and the Northport branch in north Fargo.  In 2002 and 2006
column5: the Southpointe and Northport Branches were opened serving the city's south and north sides. The Dr. James Carlson Library
column6: which replaced the earlier Southpointe Branch
column7: opened to the public on November 16
column8: 2007. A new downtown Main Library opened April 25
column9: 2009.  The Fargo Public Library is headquartered in downtown Fargo.

column2: over 1 million items were checked out from Fargo Public Library.  Books and magazines made up nearly half of the total and digital media and other non-print items made up more than a third. The rest were inter-library loans and renewals.

column1: == Culture ==
Fargo offers a wide variety of cultural opportunities for a city of its size. This is likely due
column3: to the presence of three universities in the area. Most theater and events are either promoted or produced by the universities
column4: although there are several private theater companies in the city including Fargo-Moorhead Community Theatre (FMCT)
column5: Theatre 'B' in downtown Fargo
column7: Music Theatre Fargo Moorhead
column9: The Entertainment Company and others. Music organizations in the area include the Fargo-Moorhead Opera
column11: and the Fargo-Moorhead Youth Symphony. Fargo also boasts a dance company in the Fargo-Moorhead Ballet.

column1: The Fargo Theatre is a restored 1926 Art Deco movie house that features first-run movies
column3: and other community events. The Fargodome routinely hosts concerts
column4: Broadway musicals
column5: dance performances
column7: as well as fairs and other gatherings.

column1: The Winter Carnival in Fargo is a tradition that began in 1928.

The Plains Art Museum is the largest museum of art in the state. It is in downtown Fargo and features regional and national exhibits. It also houses a large permanent collection of art. There are several other museums in Fargo including The Children's Museum at Yunker Farm
column3: The Courthouse Museum
column4: The Roger Maris Museum in West Acres Shopping Center
column5: the North Dakota State University Wall of Fame in the Scheels All Sports store and the historic Bonanzaville village (West Fargo).

column1: === Religions ===
There are at least two dozen Christian churches of different denominations in town. Fargo also has several synagogues and at least one Muslim mosque.
=== Recreation ===
The Fargo Park District operates many neighborhood parks throughout the city. The Fargo area contains the following golf courses: Edgewood Golf Course (18-hole)
column2: Fargo Country Club (18-hole) Rose Creek Golf Course (18-hole)
column3: El Zagal (9-hole)
column4: Prairiewood Golf Course (9-hole)
column5: and the new Osgood Golf Course (9-hole). In the winter Edgewood serves as a warming house and also provides cross country skis. Rose Creek and Osgood golf courses offer golfing lessons in the summer months. Fargo also has a skate park near dike west and Island park. Fargo and sister city Moorhead also hold ferry rides during the summer
column7: to promote education of the fertile soil of the Red River Valley.

column2: an NCAA Division I university with 14 varsity sports and club sports. North Dakota State's football team won five consecutive FCS National Championships between 2011 and 2015 as well as two more in 2017 and 2018 and hosted ESPN's College GameDay in 2013 and 2014.

column1: == Transportation ==
Fargo is a major transportation hub for the surrounding region. It sits at the crossroads of two major interstate highways
column2: I-29 and I-94 and is the home of an airport.

column1: Fargo is served by Hector International Airport
column2: which has the longest public runway in the state.  An Air National Guard unit and the Fixed-Base Operation Fargo Jet Center and Vic's Aircraft Sales are also at Hector.

column1: The Fargo-Moorhead metro area is served by a bus service known as MATBUS. The bus service operates routes Monday-Saturday
column2: many of which specifically cater to the area's college student population
column3: who comprise half of its ridership. Greyhound Lines
column4: Jefferson Lines and Rimrock Stages Trailways bus services additionally link Fargo to other communities.

column1: The BNSF Railway runs through the metropolitan area as successor to the Great Northern Railway and Northern Pacific Railroad. Amtrak service is provided via the Empire Builder passenger train at the Fargo Amtrak station.
The city sits at the intersection of Interstate 29 and Interstate 94. U.S. Highway 81
column3: and U.S. Highway 52 also run through the community.

column1: The street system of Fargo is structured in the classic grid pattern. Routes that run from north to south are called streets
column2: and routes that run from east to west are called avenues.

=== Arenas and auditoriums ===

Fargodome – indoor arena on the NDSU campus. It plays host to all NDSU home football games and is also used for concerts and trade shows. The facility also hosts the high school wrestling national freestyle and Greco-Roman championships take place every year.
Newman Outdoor Field – Minor League Baseball stadium
column2: host to the Fargo-Moorhead RedHawks and NDSU Bison baseball. Located at 1515 15th Ave N
column3: Fargo on NDSU campus.

column1: Reineke Fine Arts Center – On the NDSU campus. The university uses the center for concerts
column3: and other events.

column1: Fargo Civic Center – indoor arena used to host trade shows
column3: meetings
column4: community events
column5: concerts

column1: John E. Carlson Coliseum – This arena is host to the Fargo North High School and Fargo South High School hockey teams as well as the FM Jets hockey team
column2: before the team left Fargo. The arena was built in 1968 and has previously been home to the Fargo Blazers and NDSU Club hockey teams. The arena is also for figure skating. The Coliseum hosts the largest squirt hockey tournament in the world
column3: the Fargo Flyers Squirt International Hockey Tournament.

column1: Scheels Arena – On June 27
column3: Fargo held a groundbreaking for the $25 million Urban Plains Center ice hockey arena. Its first event was a Fargo Force Hockey home game on Thursday
column4: October 30
column5: 2008. The arena is used for the United States Hockey League's Fargo Force
column7: and other concerts and special events. The Urban Plains Center was renamed Scheels Arena on October 6
column8: 2010. The arena opened a second sheet of ice connected to the facility in June 2016.

== In popular culture ==

Fargo is an Academy Award–winning 1996 film which takes place primarily throughout Minnesota.  Fargo is only seen briefly at the film's opening scene set in a bar and mentioned only twice in the film. None of Fargo was shot on location in or near Fargo.  A television series based on the film debuted in 2014
column2: and occasionally featured the city in episodes.
